title: When will a new tax framework for multinational tech companies be submitted by the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)?
preds: adjusting because October is right around the corner
Regular update, no change. Only 9 days left.

There are documents but they will only be discussed at their plenary meeting October 7 or 8th. https://www.internationaltaxreview.com/article/b1n79rkv8p80q6/this-week-in-tax-pillar-one-and-pillar-two-documents-are-leaked
With the delays caused by COVID-19 and the upcoming US Presidential election there is little to no chance that a plan will be announced before 1 Oct 2020.

No chance even after 1st October.
Couple of factors that will matter :
1. US Elections.
2. COVID Vaccine.
3. Lobbying power of American Big tech post elections.

"Amidst uncertainty, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is continuing work on a proposed international agreement to address the tax challenges of the digitalised economy ... The next major deadline for the OECD’s effort to forge a global deal on taxing digital-based companies is October, when the organisation will present a detailed blueprint of a two-pillar plan ... The G20 finance ministers requested the blueprint to be completed by October, when they are scheduled to meet, because they hope to finalise an agreement on taxing the digitalised economy by the end of 2020. The timeframe may have to be extended, however." https://www.fm-magazine.com/news/2020/aug/oecd-aims-for-global-tax-agreement-this-year.html
This year, quite possibly [1], but likely not by October 1. [1] https://www.pinsentmasons.com/out-law/news/g20-reaffirm-commitment-digital-tax-agreement
There are a lot of reasons to to get it done but unlikely by Oct 1. https://www.fm-magazine.com/news/2020/aug/oecd-aims-for-global-tax-agreement-this-year.html

US aren't playing ball and the submission of a "blueprint" by the OECD isn't requested by the G20 until October https://www.pinsentmasons.com/out-law/news/g20-reaffirm-commitment-digital-tax-agreement "The G20 has asked the OECD to submit a report on the "blueprints" for each pillar at the next meeting of the G20 Finance Ministers in October."
Too many more important things going on
Will be done after USA elections
Nothing will get done before the US election in November.
No one will want to touch it from now to q4 2020
Not during this pandemic, they have other priorities, meanwhile tax already low and practically difficult to impose new regulations

https://www.oecd.org/tax/exchange-of-tax-information/oecd-releases-global-tax-reporting-framework-for-digital-platforms-in-the-sharing-and-gig-economy.htm
A reporting framework but no rules or laws agreed upon. US asked for or just pulled back from negotiations. Covid slowed discussions.
Base Rate - based on Crowd Wisdom

It looks like the OECD is still targeting getting the "blueprint" out by Oct 1st [1]. The US, though, seems unclear on where it would like to get to with this, having asked for a pause on work, but being fully committed per the sec of Treasury, to being "no longer involved" from the US trade representative  [2]. Since brinksmanship is attractive to POTUS, I can see this going either off without a hitch based on the work that is currently being done and the US just signs on OR completely collapsing, as the US does really forget about it. I am thinking it is likely the second, so bumping up the last bin. [1] https://news.bloombergtax.com/daily-tax-report-international/oecd-hoping-for-blueprints-of-digital-tax-plan-by-october
USA will block, interests are not aligned.
the world has other priorities to focus on for now.

I guess UK/The Queen of England and their multitude of tax havens all over the world (beginning with the channel islands not ending with the British Virgin Islands...) are a major obstacle to any global multilateral taxation initiatives towards a just tax framework that refers to country-wide revenues only instead of country of domicile of the corporation. The discrepancy between juridical foundation of non-taxation (due to dependence on tax domiciles) and the real world economic effects on societies have been staggering for 150 year now, and taxation fails have been crippling progress for most of the post-WWII world. Rutger Bregman speaking at Davos 2019 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r5LtFnmPruU https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gO80J7gsDm8 "It feels like I'm in a fire-fighters conference, and no one is allowed to talk about water." As soon as UK has realized they can either kiss the a** of the POTUS ("As soon as they [the EU] are out, we're in.") for a bilateral FTA and/or kiss the rests of their empire goodbye, they will want to accelerate negotiations with the EU and even accept uncomfortable terms when it comes to taxes by the end of July 2020. This in mind, it is likely some drive will come into the total stalemate of this well-analyzed and long standing , yet important, field of International Policy and diplomacy in August 2020. There are obstacles, but chances are better than ever these obstacles will be overcome.

Complexity and competing national interests, among other factors such as election cycles, imply an agreement on a framework will take a long time. Although, very small probability that some companies such as Amazon may cause a large group of nations to coalesce around some framework in the short term in light of pandemic driven disparity in fortunes of some corporations relative to others.
The pandemic pushed by the timeline from June to October, but nothing will likely get done until 2021.

The OECD held digital public consultations in mid May. This had originally been scheduled for March. It seems there would need to be  physical/remote meetings before a final plan can be submitted. And the meeting is supposed to take place in October 2020. - https://taxexecutive.org/oecd-races-toward-completing-final-report-on-digital-economy/
- https://www.grantthornton.com/library/newsletters/tax/2020/hot-topics/may-19/OECD-delays-digital-tax-agreement-to-october.aspx
time is running out and no real sign of traction. Moving forecast from 95% to 99% after October
I think covid will delay this
I'll cave and join the consensus that this is not likely to happen prior to October. No data, just consensus.

Baseline: The summer of 2020 is the deadline  High stakes and complicated matters involving defining and tracking economic activity in the age of ML, defining fair market rates in intra-group transactions and defining a minimum level of taxation above 0. The work has been going on for decades but in those decades the world has changes significantly technologically.
Group has been working towards the still scheduled meeting in July for framework finalisation
Perhaps this can be negotiated on Zoom, with the dog barking and kids still running around. Or perhaps not.
The window in now closing on the second bucket.
I cannot see any delays yet to Beps Berlin July 2020 which is the stated target. Looks like it will go online.

There continues to be conversation about this tax framework even during the crisis from the members, feeling that it needs to move ahead [1]. Some are urging the OECD to delay and wait for the effects from the pandemic to stabilize [2] and there seems to be concern that it will be delayed [3].  From these, if it happens at all this year, it will be late in the year. [1] https://news.bloombergtax.com/daily-tax-report/tax-virus-briefing-federal-relief-corporate-struggles-continue
[2] https://taxfoundation.org/oecd-global-digital-tax-continues/
[3] https://www.icij.org/investigations/panama-papers/crumbling-economies-must-tackle-tax-evasion-to-tackle-coronavirus-crisis-experts-warn/
Things do not seem to be improving too rapidly here.
Covid will ensure that this is not submitted until the dust has settled
Nothing can happen now. Not a priority issue. Whole thing will be reviewed post COVID19
maintaining current forecast. Updating for passage of time.
Call for unity started in February... (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-g20-tax/lets-come-together-to-tax-tech-giants-say-g20-officials-eying-100-billion-boost-idUSKCN20G0DD) and will last long.
It turns out working from home makes this easier. The kids have some good ideas and could speed this process up.

Maybe they can do it working from home and minding the kids at the same time. 
With a July 1 goal a slip to Sept may provide enough wiggle room to get it done.
However, the virus has confounded most every other plans for progress.
updating due to passage of time.
Working from home with kids underfoot is not likely to speed this negotiation. The kids may have better ideas, but it would still need legal review.
in this crisis time it's not the priority

I think the Europeans were afraid of Trump as he could impose harsh tariffs, but now the US economy could be headed towards a recession, in an election year... could this be the best time for the Europeans to force in a deal? 
Failure to do so will result in several EU countries individually imposing digital taxes anyway. This summer maybe there could be heightened interests in completing the tax framework, by November (US elections) it could be too late! Plus the Democrats would likely support this venture.
They gave themselves till end of year. The counter argument is that they will need funds to combat the economic slowdown due to coronavirus.
Can this be done with everyone working from home?
It likely will not happen with international turmoil or near to US election.
Moving off zero, to something a little warmer, but still not believing it will happen in this timeframe.
They will want to delay till after our Presidential election

Not until Brexit regulation and tax framework is confirmed or almost confirmed. Plus big tech has lots of influence and little incentive to change the status quo soon. If economy gets worse in 2020, countries may even be concerned with the potential pull-out of these firms.
Once again @Hammer-Time offers a postion convincing enough that I'll follow him into the deep end.

FYI only - from The Economist
“Spain’s government has approved a digital-services tax on big technology companies. But the 3% tax will only take effect in December, allowing more time for the OECD, a club of rich nations, to negotiate an international agreement on digital taxes. When the French government announced its own digital tax last year, America threatened stiff retaliatory tariffs until France said it would hold off until the end of this year.”

https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/02/14/business/bc-eu-security-conference-facebook.html
By end of year is the time frame. Traditionally negotiations tend to take the time alloted.
US/Trump will not support a new framework

I don't think the Trump administration is particularly interested in reaching an accord which would increase the ability of foreign countries to tax American technology companies. Accordingly, they will drag their feet and refused to cooperate.

With President Trump seemingly unwilling to negotiate such an international tax accord, especially one that would overwhelmingly hit U.S. tech companies, the chance of any such accord being reached before the end of the year seems negligible.
In order to shut down in country noise about taxation on Tech giants there will be more pressure to get the job done

When will a new tax framework for multinational tech companies be submitted by the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)?
I'll align my forecast with @Tetbury as his argument resonates with my thinking and I like @cdob63 numbers.
France agreed to delay tech tax until end 2020

The OECD says its planning to publish this framework in 2020.
The US (Trump) says if any country jumps the gun and introduces its own tax unilaterally the US will retaliate. 
France and the UK had both planned to jump the gun. France has postponed its tax until December 2020, so far the UK has said it will go ahead with its own tax in April 2020.  It would be easy for US politicians to claim that the OECD proposals are an international conspiracy to steal money from the US. So for political reasons I would guess that the OECD would delay submitting the new tax framework until after the US Presidential elections. I am pretty sure that the OECD would not want to stir up opposition to the tax in the US before it had started.  On the other hand voters in Europe and many countries will be stirred up if the taxation of multinational tech companies is not increased significantly soon.  Hence the pressure from the UK and France. So my guess would be that the OECD would schedule its framework release for its scheduled meeting in Paris on 5th December 2020.

The deadline is by the end of the year but 130 countries are involved. There may be acceptance of a minimum tax all companies would pay. France has put their tech tax on hold to see what this process brings. If you hear the French talking about implementing their tax then you know no framework is near. Going to shift a few points to May 1 to Sept 30 because they are eorking hard to come up with something to avoid trade wars over this.
Pace is moving fast, but final consensus will take time. An underperforming Eu economy will delay this.

When will a new tax framework for multinational tech companies be submitted by the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)?
"Time is ticking ticking into the future"
Tax reform is to Bi-Partisan to get through quickly.
Going with consensus. To many factions.

Much of the progress that has been made in proposals have been based on adding European produced luxury goods and automobiles to the mix that was largely aimed at technology / digital businesses that were based in America. This concession to Washington DC makes it much likelier to secure agreement on a plan to be submitted however the size and impact on digital companies will ultimately lead the US to disagree to the plan.
The tech companies will fight it all the way. Facebook will post copious amounts of disinformation on the subject.

Because Trump will only accept a deal that is beneficial to US: tax paid in country of origin. Other countries have different interests: tax payed in vountry where benefits were realized. An agreement therefor will take time.
America seems to be against it.  EU might unilaterally or in  co operation with other like minded countries announce

Thanks to the following for their sourcing, reasoning, and time spent on this question @hrm123 and @P-Drash and @cmeinel  Looking at the details of the question, we have to consider how it will be resolved.  The question and expanded explanation indicates only the submission of the plan to the Inclusive Framework, not full adoption.  The two pillars released last year set the context for the current discussion.  If the countries meeting at Davos or the G20 in the KSA come to an agreement or a partial agreement (Pillar 1 or Pillar 2) it seems that would resolve this question.   A couple of issues I considered - 
Number of countries participating - 130 or more with varying interests and impacts to their national tax base.  It doesn't make it impossible, but it makes it complicated.   Timing of venues or events to conduct negotiations or submit proposals (https://news.bloombergtax.com/daily-tax-report/insight-25)
- First and foremost, the political negotiations over Pillar One issues will continue...  into the second half of 2020. The negotiations will not take place in public, but as in any political process, one can expect a certain amount of strategic leaking of selected information.
- Second, the parallel work stream focused on Pillar Two will also continue;
- At some point during the first half of 2020 it is likely that a public consultation paper will be issued, requesting comments on issues relating to the undertaxed-payments rule and perhaps other elements of Pillar Two as well.
- "Third, we can expect to see more unilateral DSTs being proposed or enacted... (which will) maintain the importance of the Inclusive Framework’s efforts"
- Mr. Le Maire said that if the United States imposed tariffs during the negotiating period it would effectively end the talks. He added that other European countries were in the process of establishing similar taxes, with about 15 countries around the world planning to impose their own national digital tax by June.  (https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/07/business/economy/us-france-digital-tax.html?action=click&module=News&pgtype=Homepage)
- US and France meeting in near term
- The Inclusive Framework is set to hold a plenary session in the hope of reaching an agreement in February. (https://www.internationaltaxreview.com/article/b1jxt00ggw7s77/tax-nationalism-goes-to-the-world-economic-forum) 
- G20 meeting not until November Amount of revenue or potential revenue impacted (impact relates to pace and inclusiveness of negotiations)
 - The framework proposal from last fall applies only to multinationals with annual revenues of about $825 million or higher. It excludes manufacturing suppliers and resource extraction companies, like oil companies. (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/09/us/politics/tech-giants-taxes-oecd.html)
- “Amazon welcomes the publication of these proposals by the O.E.C.D., which are an important step forward,” a spokeswoman said Wednesday in an email. An election wildcard - 
Despite the pressure of the DSTs to keep the issue in the forefront, the US Treasury's statements on the pillar one have likely impacted the likelihood of adoption and possibly new proposals in a U.S. Election year. (https://www.forbes.com/sites/taxnotes/2020/01/14/a-tax-too-far-pillar-1-we-hardly-knew-you/#1923981313ed)  Despite not needing all the players to agree, without U.S. backing, there isn't much point to a proposal.  
** The U.S. election are a potential distraction to the negotiations if they are trending away from U.S. interests or factor driving a compromise if President Trump seeks an economic "win"  during the campaign.

When will a new tax framework for multinational tech companies be submitted by the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)?
Walking this back down slowly, going closer to consensus.
First forecast without much digging into the details - mostly based on provided sources and other forecasters' discussion.
pressure for countries to have big tech is far too great and they will not want to alienate them
A multinational tax framework is not in the interest of the tech industry. The industry is engaged in talks for their image's sake. National tax administrations also have diverging interests.
Major G20 meetings aren't until November 2020.

I am realigning my forecast to resonate with @Chassty. 
The escalation of tarrifs on France is heating up the stew pot. Hattip @Hammer-Time and NYT for today's update
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/07/business/economy/us-france-digital-tax.html?action=click&module=News&pgtype=Homepage
Not sure what will come out, but someone could get burned in the process.

FYI from the Economist 
“Imported beauty products, champagne and handbags will be in the firing line today at the United States Trade Representative’s hearing over France’s digital-services tax. Frustrated with the slow pace of multilateral efforts to reform the global tax system—and the piddling amounts paid in France by tech giants—last July the French government introduced a revenue tax on certain big digital companies. But a USTR investigation concluded the policy discriminated against American companies and has proposed imposing retaliatory tariffs on $2.4bn of French imports. It is hard to see how further confrontation can be avoided. A grand bargain on tax reform could defuse tensions, but the Trump administration has recently seemed to sour on the idea. Phil Hogan, the EU’s trade commissioner, will try to soothe relations when he meets with Robert Lighthizer, the USTR’s top official, in Washington next week. But at this point, his task may simply be one of damage control.”

When will a new tax framework for multinational tech companies be submitted by the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)?   "Plenary meetings of the IF on BEPS generally take place twice a year: in January at the OECD in Paris, and in May/June in general in an IF member country." The desire to derive revenue from digital transaction oritented Multinational Enterprises is huge - getting everyone to agree to terms is hard.
Difficult to get any agreement about taxes
Too many moving parts for this thing to reliably happen anytime soon.
There is no consensus between countries to support such a measure
OECD will release more details from the economic impact analysis in Q1 2020

Frameworks for revitalizing tax are challenging at easiest and complicated beyond most understanding. I'm sure ideas will be submitted but no formal tax framework. Finding taxation in semi autonomous companies will be challenging.

https://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/about/ says "over 130 countries" are participating in this effort.  Usually it takes a long time for getting so many nations to cooperate.  While unanimous agreement is not essential, the more the better. See also https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/930401by @cafebedouin
"make America great again" vs international cooperation

I think U.S. refusal to cooperate or “latest proposal on reform” will slow down an already complicated process. 
https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.cnbc.com/amp/2019/12/04/reuters-america-u-s-proposal-on-international-tax-reform-threatens-deadlines-oecd.html
Pressure is on, long-standing topic, current system not sustainable.  Some reform likely, although perhaps incremental rather than big.

When you hear "over 135 countries" and "international collaboration to end tax avoidance", you know it's going to be madness because not only do these countries need to agree on the plan, they are going to have to get a significant portion of the multinationals onboard. This is not something that happens quickly. Here's a fun exercise, read through this article and imagine trying to explain this to your average voter and what the various multinational companies will do if they don't like it, and chances are good they aren't going to like a new tax regime.[1] [1] https://news.bloombergtax.com/daily-tax-report/insight-taxing-multinationals-the-globe-proposal-for-a-global-minimum-tax
